You check the servers and everything looks OK, but other corporate services look down too. After 5-10 minutes of checking, miraculously they all start working again with no changes being made. You call the corporate people to ask WTF, and they seem to be completely unaware anything happened.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-08 22:43

@Matter I can see why they do, because the devices they purchase provide a function they like. I won't argue with that, they're very handy. I think the fact that they're selling their privacy is KNOWN, but it's not something they think about so it's not as big of a weight on their mind. I love the idea of them myself, and I really wish privacy respecting options like Mycroft were bigger players in the market.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-08 21:51

I've been watching the announcements coming out of CES, and I'm torn. I love the idea of smart homes, cars, and devices. The problem here is that Google and Amazon are dominating that market, and neither have any respect for personal privacy. I want projects like Mycroft to compete here, but they're not even a blip on the radar right now. Right now, it looks like winner of the battle between the two titans will control our information in the future. We don't get a say.

Mike Stone @mike 2019-01-06 06:46

@hund@linuxrocks.online Heh, not as always unfortunately. I met my wife on IRC in 1995, and even though Mosaic had been out for a couple years, Gopher and Usenet were still very popular among Internet users. These days it seems most people think the Web and the Internet are the same thing. IRC and Usenet are still chugging along, but they're not quite in the forefront of the Internet like they used to be.

I'm going to sound like an idiot.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-31 20:37

@brandon I have to manually disable forwarding too, but I schedule my phone to go on Do Not Disturb mode. After 5:00, my phone goes into DND, and only people in my Contacts ring through. I have my emergency on-call numbers stored in my contacts, and a couple people from work that can call me in case of emergency, but everybody else goes straight to voicemail. I can pick it up the following day.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-31 20:35

@blaubachn Yea, I agree. I think those "Trends" do have quite a bit of overlap.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-31 19:00

@brandon We're actually a fully ePhone place. No phones on desks at all. I have a Plantronics headset that connects to Cisco software on my computer, and that's my phone. Voicemails can either be listened to via the Cisco software (acting like a phone) or via an attachment that's sent as an attachment in email. Personally, I prefer the email attachment and can play those back without being annoyed on my personal cell even. I've taken to just forwarding my work phone to my cell anyway. Faster.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-27 03:46

@fredmbarros It looks like it's helping quite a lot. I'm surprised to be honest. I installed it and did very little else other than enable it. I've been on the laptop for the last 2 hours and it's still at about 70% battery. It's estimating 2.5 more hours of use right now. That'll be between 4 and 5 hours of use on a charge, which is not spectacular, but it's significantly better than what I have been seeing. And that's just basically installing it and turning it on. Pretty impressive.

All of that works perfectly in Solus.

Mike Stone boosted
sigrok @sigrok 2018-12-24 15:11

#sigrok has joined the #fediverse! We'll be posting announces and random other stuff over at @sigrok, with additional stuff from individual developer accounts.

Quick #introduction: sigrok is a FOSS project for all kinds of test&measurement gear, including logic analyzers, oscilloscopes, multimeters, programmable power supplies, and lots more.

Portable libs, protocol decoders written in #python, various CLI and GUI frontends.

Website/wiki: https://sigrok.org

#introductions #development

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-20 17:42

I like this idea, but obviously there are quite a few shortcomings to that approach. Discoverability and the fact that most people on Facebook don't have the technical capability of building and maintaining their own website. I feel like there's opportunity in ActivityPub for this idea, as well as a federated Wordpress type CMS where people could register their own pages and get updates from their friends.

Thoughts?

"We Should Replace Facebook With Personal Websites"

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-18 20:12

@fdroid_lurker Sometimes, but if you argue a review is advertising, and a review can compare and contrast competing products, then advertising can promote multiple products without specifically demoting either. Example, if you review the latest Ubuntu release and compare it to the latest Fedora release. You may find them roughly equal if different in specific areas in a review.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-18 18:15

@fdroid_lurker Very true. The old adage is, "There is no such thing as bad publicity", so by default any review, whether good or bad, is advertising. I'd argue the difference between them is value and truth to the intended target of that "advertising". Advertising in its basest sense may lack truth and offer very little of value beyond promotion of a product. A review, while still advertising, provides additional information and a hopefully external opinion on the product.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-18 17:44

I watched this yesterday, and I did find it funny.

"Guy Builds A Glitter Bomb Fart-Spray Package To Get Back At Package Thieves"

https://geekologie.com/2018/12/guy-builds-a-glitter-bomb-fart-spray-pac.php

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-18 17:06

@stevenroose Sory, the @fosstodon account isn't really monitored.

The concept is this: We opened a Patreon account to fun Fosstodon, and we take in from the community more than is required to keep this site running. We've promised that, as a community, we will choose FOSS projects to support with funds that build up beyond a 6+ month buffer space. The community in general makes suggestions, the Patreons vote on those suggestions, and we donate to the winning project as a community.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-18 16:24

It's Tuesday already! Have you gone to the Hub to offer a FOSS project you'd like to see funded by Fosstodon? Do it now or @kev will make a sad face. 😢

https://hub.fosstodon.org/project-donations/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-17 23:25

@mattmcnutt Google/Alphabet never made that claim that I'm aware of, though it's certainly been brought up as a possibility. Most seem to just see the reorg as a way to separate Google's traditional businesses like search away from their "moonshot" projects. Those people seem to think of it more as a way to ease management of divergent technology and methodology. Still, more than possible it was to keep the big bad government off their tail.

@codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-17 23:15

@codesections My wife has that same problem with all of her knitting stuff. I always find it on the couch.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-17 23:14

@codesections I agree that Google has an unhealthy amount of control over the Internet in virtually every area, but it's going to be pretty hard to argue it in a court of law. Given, as a lawyer you probably have a better understanding of this than I do, but Microsoft paid vendors to give customers their OS, they surprised other OS competition by threatening OEMs. They tied their applications to their OS. Google has done none of that. None of their products are "forced" on a customer that way.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-17 23:06

I don't know if these allegations are true or not, but even if they are, I have little sympathy for Microsoft. It sounds like a play right out of their playbook.

"Former Edge intern says Google sabotaged Microsoft's browser"

https://www.neowin.net/news/former-edge-intern-says-google-sabotaged-microsofts-browser

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-17 15:23

@codesections I've heard some pretty good things about ProtonMail, but I've never used it myself. Might be a good alternative though.

Note: the final decision will be reserved for our Patrons.

Patreon page: https://patreon.com/fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-14 23:47

@cigarBGuitarEfx The Lincoln quote is accurate, if lacking in context. It's from a letter he wrote to Horace Greeley. In it he differentiates between what his view of his "official duty" was (to preserve the Union), and his PERSONAL preference (that all men every where could be free).

There is no evidence that Robert E. Lee made the attributed statement.

http://www.abrahamlincolnonline.org/lincoln/speeches/greeley.htm

@AtlasFreeman@liberdon.com @Liberty4Masses@liberdon.com @gmcgath@liberdon.com @billblake2018@liberdon.com

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 14:33

@colomar I agree. My biggest complaint about AR/VR is that they're considered separate things. Inserting Virtuality into Reality with varying levels (all the way up to 100%) is where these fields (this field) need to go.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 14:28

@stevenroose Is AR/VR going to amount to anything? Maybe, but we're going to be left behind unless we start to step up to these kinds of things first.

2/2

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 14:28

@stevenroose That's a good question, and one I don't really have a good answer for. What I do this is this. One of the FOSS community's greatest weaknesses (maybe even it's greatest) is it's tendency to follow on existing tech. A corporate giant makes something, and then someone comes along and makes a FOSS version of it. That always puts the FOSS version into a "catch up" mode right away, instead of an "innovate" mode.

1/2

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 14:22

@kungtotte That's a great book. I've read it a couple times, but not recently. Might be time to pick it up again.

@hund@linuxrocks.online @geotechland

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 14:21

@pranav Unfortunately, Degoogling isn't in my immediate future. I require either an Android phone or an iPhone for work. Personally, I prefer Android over iOS.

@aadilayub

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-12 03:57

@colomar Agreed. I'm not sure AR and VR are the future at this point, but AI definitely is, and virtual assistants are built on AI (kinda). If we want too stay relevant, we need to be present in these fields.

https://www.geekwire.com/2016/windows-apps-virtual-reality-envelop-vr-unveils-3d-immersive-computing-platform/

@kelbot They might get some novelty sales that way, but there's a reason those kind of devices are rare these days. If it's not a phone, most people will have to carry another device. Aaron *MOVED TO @crash* @theartguy 2018-12-06 01:55

NOTE TO NEW USERS:

Mastodon's a cool place, but it's private like a local coffee shop, not a home bathroom.

Remember that the admin of your instance can see EVERYTHING you post, including direct posts. They can even disable 2 factor authentication, if you have it enabled (and you should. No really, enable that stuff now.)

Bottom line: Find an instance where you feel you can trust your admin, and don't send direct toots unless you trust the admin at the recipient's instance as well.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-06 05:18

@CrowderSoup I have to confess, I have no idea how Tumblr works.

@write_as @dansup

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-06 04:39

@write_as

- I think there should be an admin setting to make the timeline public or not, as there is in Mastodon. Also, an admin setting for the DEFAULT permissions for posts. Each profile should be able to override that default at both the profile level and the post level.

- I would expect to interact on a limited basis. Follow certainly. I'm not sure about how boosting is going to work. Reply, no. I think that would encourage people to reply without reading.

@CrowderSoup @dansup

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-06 04:10

@write_as Yes, yes I do.

khloris @efflorescence 2018-12-04 16:32

for the older users on here:
use this as another opportunity to strengthen mastodon. open up to new people, talk to them, engage them. help them find communities on here that they fit into best, even if that isn't yours. the more we engage, the better we retain.

we want to keep as many new people as we can, to perpetuate the ideas this platform stands on, and to drive decentralization into the mainstream.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-04 16:29

@nebunez I know what you mean. Microsoft contributing to my favorite FOSS projects kind of makes me feel ooky. I don't mind people contributing to make it better, but I just don't trust them.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-04 16:27

@geotechland I'm kind of on the fence. Most (if not all) Chromiuim development is done by Google, who then builds their own browser version (Chrome) on top of it. If Windows has a built in Chromium browser, it could make people less motivated to download Chrome, which could make Google less inclined to put resources into it's development.

I don't know. I'm still trying to figure out how I feel about this. I'm not sure it's a good thing, but I'm also not sure it's a bad thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-04 16:24

@d4klutz If you see any inappropriate material on our local timeline, please report it. I'm all for free speech and I have no desire to censor people's thoughts, but this is an instance dedicated to FOSS, not graphic adult content. There are other instances for that kind of thing.

@rpcutts @fatboy

codesections @codesections 2018-12-03 19:39

Since we seem to be in the middle of (another) user influx, I'm reposting some getting started resources:

*Blog posts*
https://www.codesections.com/blog/mastodon-elevator-pitch/ (me)
https://kevq.uk/how-does-mastodon-work/
https://kevq.uk/getting-started-with-mastodon/ (both @kev https://nolanlawson.com/2018/08/31/mastodon-and-the-challenges-of-abuse-in-a-federated-system/ @nolan

*Alternative front-ends*
https://pinafore.social/
https://brutaldon.online/
https://halcyon.cybre.space/

*Tool for finding people to follow*
https://communitywiki.org/trunk

*issue tracker for software bugs*
https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon

Let me know what I've forgotten!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:57

@kev Right now I have a laptop and a tablet, but I find I do most of the "tablety" things on my phone, and my tablet is mostly just for media consumption. I own a Pixel C because my currently laptop is too big and too heavy to be truly portable, but the Pixel C is not a great laptop replacement. That means I currently have 2 devices where neither do their job terribly well. I'd rather move to a portable laptop where I could still comfortably consume media and a phone for my other tasks.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:54

@qwazix Thanks! I'll give it a look!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:46

@g All these factors come together in my mind and it seems I can move my current laptop to a media server, and replace it with a detachable laptop. That way, I have a spiffy i7 driving Plex, and a laptop I can dock and run a full Linux distro on but still detach the screen for media consumption if I just want to sit on the couch and watch Netflix.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:44

@g All the rest of the "portable" functions I do, I tend to do on my phone rather than using a full blown tablet. If I'm going to be mobile, I want to reduce the amount of stuff I have to travel with. I already have kids I travel with and they NEED a LOT of stuff, so I like to keep my personal needs minimized. Still, I don't want to be watching TV or Netflix on my phone. I love the tablet interface for that.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:41

@g Of course, if I do that, I'm going to need a new daily driver. I made a mistake the last time when I bought the laptop and went with a 17" screen. That works for some people, but it's a pain to be portable with for me. Because of that, it's mostly been a desktop computer in laptop form. To compensate for that, I bought a Pixel C. I like it, but the keyboard and Android creates limitations for me that I wouldn't have with a laptop. Mostly these days I use it for media consumption.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 16:38

@g True. I'm in the market for a couple reasons. The biggest (and the main driver) is my media server in my house. It was my main computer before I bought my laptop. It's about 7 years old and was midrange at the time. Recently the proc has been getting pegged doing all the transcoding required for my Plex, so I'm looking to replace it. Instead of buying a new media server, I was planning on migrating my laptop to use as the media server with a Synology for storage.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 01:11

@nebunez Thanks, I'll keep that in mind! I'm not a huge fan of the fold convertibles because I hate having the keyboard on the back of the device while I'm holding it. That being said, I haven't really found anything that's really 100%, and that still may be the best option!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 00:43

@DonMcCollough Thought about it, and it's not off the table, but the privacy aspects of it do concern me. Plus, even though Google has made massive advances with ChromeOS, it's still not up to par with a full desktop OS. I do like the more dedicated touch interface though because if I were to go with one of these Spectre laptops, I'm not sure how well Linux would perform with a touch only interface. I imagine Gnome would be OK, but I'm sure not running i3 on the thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-12-03 00:31

I'm in the market for a new laptop and a new tablet. My laptop is over 4 years old, and my tablet is no longer supported. Of course, the bright idea struck me, "Why not just get one device that accomplishes both tasks?"

I've been looking around at detachables. I don't want to go Android. Too many limitations. iPad isn't on the list. There's some Samsung devices, but not a fan of them either.

I ran across the this:

https://store.hp.com/us/en/pdp/hp-spectre-x2---12-c052nr

Anyone have experience with using Linux on one?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-30 16:24

@pranav I tested it out with my wife's phone. It worked pretty well. The voice is a little more stilted than the normal assistant when you're talking to it. On the phone receiving the call, things are pretty straight forward. There's buttons to tap for requesting additional information and "end call" responses. I didn't notice any "please hold" option in case you're wanting to take the call though. All in all, would be good for suspected spammers but I probably wouldn't use it in other cases.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-28 06:12

@lee8oi Very true, but I think network would be a secondary concern to oxygen at that point.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-27 21:33

@codesections Yep, but man muscle memory will kill you when it comes to those large directories. I've run into a couple with thousands of files and I've cded into the directory and that ls just flies out of my fingers before I even realize I've done it. The good part about that is there's PLENTY of time to face palm after you've done it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-27 21:28

@codesections It's not SUPER crazy. It'll work as long as you're always getting the file name you need to access programmatically and not though some file system tools. You can never do an ls or a sort or a stat of files in that location. Ever. It'll be a dead spot in your file system. Otherwise everything will take a really long time and require a ton of resources.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-27 21:13

@erikstl Nope. I think it's got a lot to do with that same idea though. There are a lot of people (and I don't disagree with them) that look at Gopher as a "preweb" version of the web that has never been corrupted by corporate interests. It's closer to the original ideal of the web than the current web is.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-27 21:08

@erikstl There's been a lot of resurgence of #gopher, especially in the "nerdier" circles lately. I've been looking at spinning up a Gopher server to mirror my website.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-25 18:25

@squinter Understood. Bots aren't explicitly forbidden here on Fosstodon, but they're pretty rare, and the overt ones are generally silenced so they don't spam the Local Timeline. We're not a huge fan of bots cluttering up the timeline, so I'd guess that at least while @kev and I are the admins of this system (foreseeable future) you're not going to see a large number of bots here.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-24 20:06

As @jdormit@mastodon.technology said in his post, his "mission is to open up the entire internet", and that includes "every website, every social network, and every blog". I love that idea, and I hope that he's not the only one that has it. I'm not coder enough to pull this stuff off, but I'm sure there are others out there that can, and hopefully they take inspiration from this.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-21 14:33

@brandon At work it's a combination of email, Skype, and HipChat. I get hundreds of emails a day for various things. Corporate communication, log dumps, general departmental information, as well as requests and ticket assignments. I answer probably 30-50 of those. 1 to 1 quick stuff goes to Skype. HipChat we use for automated notifications and communication about those notifications. It's a dumping ground of communication mediums. Almost all stuff I don't use outside of work.

@lee8oi

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-21 00:06

@lee8oi Agreed, but I think that's unfortunate. There's really no reason email should be our "online identity" any more than a Twitter account or Instagram. It would be nice to have a service like Keybase that was used for online authentication where accounts could be verified with the service and tied to that particular identity.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-19 21:29

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-19 20:23

@Antanicus On a fundamental level I suppose, but I don't mind an AI assistant knowing things about me and my family as long as I have complete control over where that data goes and who has access to it. For example, if a Mycroft Personal Server resided in my house, and any and all requests I made went to that internal server. Then Internet requests could be routed through VPN and Tor and I'd have the same functionality but without selling my personal data.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-19 20:03

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-19 18:31

This is why an open source option is imperative. Microsoft is basically throwing in the towel here, and even at their best they weren't a great option anyway. That doesn't really affect the "serious" assistant field since Amazon and Google already dominate, and Cortana and Siri are next in line with single digit market penetration. We really need an option that isn't just a data miner in a very poor disguise.

https://betanews.com/2018/11/18/microsoft-cortana-failure-echo-dot/

fridaysforfuture, but everyday @paulfree14 2018-11-12 09:05

"People are still more worried that a third-party company like #CambridgeAnalytica used facebook's data instead of what they should actually be worried about: that #Facebook had that data to begin with"
"If Cambridge Analytica can sway elections and referenda with a relatively small subset of facebook's data, imagine what facebook can and does do with the full set." - @aral

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-14 21:06

@amolith I don't have any unique insight for you unfortunately. Just standard stuff. Clear cookies and cache. Test with another browser to see if it's coming from FF or if it's something larger. Maybe disable any adblock or javascript block extensions that might be messing with anything in the background and see if that fixes it. If it does, re-enable one at a time till you isolate the culprit. I don't know, @kev might have some better ideas.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-14 20:51

Mike Stone boosted
rnickson [MIGRATING] @rnickson 2018-11-14 08:40

Hello,
I'm 15 years old student passionate about Open Source software. In my free time, I often work on my own open projects.
This year I take part in #GoogleCodeIn. As a part of my current task I created a Drupal plugin, that allows to login in to a Drupal website with Mastodon account (actually for one instance only, and requires manual OAuth2 key pair creating, but that's to be done later).
https://www.drupal.org/project/social_auth_mastodon

Mike Stone boosted
GetTogether.Community @GetTogetherComm 2018-11-12 15:57

The intent was always to support federation, and there is some very basic event federation already using simple JSON feeds.

Fully ActivityPub support (needed to interoperate with Mastodon) is more complicated, and while the data export is working, we need contributors to help with the pub/sub part of the protocol.

There's an open issue for it here: https://github.com/GetTogetherComm/GetTogether/issues/60

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-12 16:33

@colomar I agree wholeheartedly.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-12 16:30

@technoslick These days I'm pretty lazy about the whole thing. I'm running Mint 19, which has been super easy to use and setup. I refuse to do family tech support (and my wife doesn't ask me to since she's more than got a handle on her own stuff). My work involves a lot of RHEL, so I don't do a lot of computer stuff at home these days.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-12 16:02

@colomar Not that the Fed isn't useful in and of itself. Both Local and the Fed give people instant access to community where other social networks require knowing people or searching. Either is OK, but not as effective in my opinion.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-12 16:02

@colomar I would agree, which is also why I think Local Feeds are so important. People can join instances that reflect their interests and get instant access to a community of people with similar interests. People who join more general instances don't get that benefit as much as people who join more specific ones. They're just getting a smaller version of the Fed.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-11 21:26

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-11 19:28

@Sporiff We also had a web site and a mailing list (I'm still on it even though I haven't attended a meeting in almost 15 years). We would talk about subjects we would like to cover ahead of time.

At this point, I'd also suggest using @GetTogetherComm instead of MeetUp. There are some really interesting options available these days that didn't exist back in the day.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-11 19:20

@Sporiff Ours varied. We met once a month, and some months we just hung out and talked about random stuff. Others we would have guests and formal presentations or demonstrations of various things. We started ours by hanging posters and targeting areas where you're more likely to run into people who would be interested. Universities were a big one for us. We also had business cards that we just handed out to people we saw wearing nerd shirts around town. We set things up with MeetUp too.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:59

@Duder963 Yep. In fact, I think it's still growing, so it's becoming more of a thing than it was. :mastodon:

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:58

@erikstl It's no problem. If you were wondering, then someone else was probably wondering too.

The Local timeline is (IMHO) one of the best features of Mastodon (and it can be horrible too depending on the instance you've chosen). It automatically gives you access to people right from the start instead of beginning with a void and needing to search for people from scratch.

@ckoul

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:55

@clerical@toot.cafe I would love it if the data was pure and unbiased, but because these AIs are created the way they are, they're probably going to show MORE bias, not less. A human will at least pretend that they're not being biased (or make an effort to not be overt about it), and AI doesn't know it's "supposed" to do that. Without AIs and data sets specifically curated to eliminate those biases, they're obviously going to be there. As far as I'm aware, no one is curating their data sets that way.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:49

@erikstl The local timeline is all the public posts made on your instance minus replies and boosts. The Home timeline is all the posts made by people you follow, which includes replies and boosts. The public timeline is kind of a mini version of the Federated timeline.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:42

@pranav Sounds like a better way to do things. In the United States, "competition" is more illusion than reality. I can change carrier, but all major carriers are doing this. Smaller carriers can't afford coverage unless they lease network space from one of the big networks. The FCC mandated back in 1999 that phones (all of them) have a tracking chip built in (for our own good) so emergency calls come with location data. My more pessimistic side doubts their motivations.

@kev @porus @ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:39

I don't understand why people are surprised by this. AIs are written by people with bias, tested by people with bias, and trained on data sets that contain biases. Why are we shocked that the AIs end up biased? Seems a foregone conclusion to me until we can figure out a better way for them to work.

https://www.thenational.ae/opinion/comment/discrimination-is-not-just-the-domain-of-humans-now-artificial-intelligence-is-showing-gender-bias-too-1.789470

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 16:18

@kev @pranav It's more than just that, at least here in the United States. Carriers (we're not talking Google or Facebook) have been tracking locations in real time and selling the information to ad networks. Some have "promised" to stop selling the information, but I have yet to see one "promise" to stop collecting the information in the first place. The fact of the matter is, if you're carrying a cell phone that's turned on, you're being tracked.

https://www.zdnet.com/article/senator-rebukes-carriers-sharing-real-time-location-data/

@porus @ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 15:09

@Sporiff Welcome back then. Hopefully your experience this time around is much better. We have a great community here, and feel free to let me know if you have any questions or have any concerns.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-08 14:31

@pranav I'd say that Firefox meets those requirements. I personally use Vivaldi, which has been great for me, and which I'd also say meets those requirements.

In the mobile space, Firefox is probably one of your better options. Vivaldi doesn't exist there. Frankly though, once you're in mobile space, you can pretty much assume you're being spied on by someone. There is no mobile platform that doesn't allow for that. Even if your phone/browser doesn't your carrier does.

@kev @porus @ericbuijs

It's not "morally wrong" or illegal in any way. It just feels icky.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-07 16:35

@BO41 It's not just you.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-07 16:35

@kelbot Yea, there's been some UI changes in the recent release that I'm not sure were an improvement, though I do appreciate the extra functionality.

Disable temporarily disables access to the account.

Silence leaves the account active, but only people that follow the account will see it's posts, regardless of their individual post settings.

Suspend makes the account go bye-bye. Access gone, posts removed. We almost never use this option. We would discuss on Keybase before using.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-03 18:25

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-03 18:23

@kev Probably the Apple angle. In my experience, there are two groups within the FOSS community when it comes to Apple.

1. Views Apple as an improvement to Google. Apple doesn't collect the data about you that Google does, so they're a step in the right direction.

2. Views Apple as worse than Google. Google allows you to customize your phone and switch out just about everything about it. Apple barely lets you sort your icons.

When you ditch Google for Apple, you're riling up one of those.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-03 17:58

@joseph That sucks. We totally understand that life happens. Hopefully you can get something worked out here soon for everybody involved, including your canine friend.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-01 23:10

@rcramalho In my personal (and admittedly extremely limited experience) there's some variation in the file system, system utilities are different (though similar), and scheduled vs. rolling release. Arch actually has a much more detailed comparison on their wiki.

https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Arch_compared_to_other_distributions#Debian

@hund@linuxrocks.online @jason @kev @timapple @kelbot

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-01 20:42

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-01 18:24

@jason My most obscure is an OS called Oberon. I ran it for a couple weeks as a school project. Was kind of fun, and there were some interesting ideas. I don't do that much these days though.

@kelbot @timapple @kev @hund@linuxrocks.online

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-01 18:23

@kelbot I wouldn't remember either, but I know I moved in with some friends in college in the spring of 97. They graduated in 98. They were the ones who introduced me to it when they ran MKLinux on a Mac they had. I also ran it at work sometime between 96 and 98, so 98 is feeling like a safe bet, but it could have been earlier.

I've actually been made fun of on bird site for using an "easy" distro by people who haven't been alive as long as I've been using Linux.

@hund@linuxrocks.online @jason @kev @timapple

Mike Stone @mike 2018-11-01 18:10

@hund@linuxrocks.online I've been using Linux for almost exactly 20 years now, and I'm running Mint 19. I've toyed with Arch, and occasionally I make forays into RPM based systems, but for the most part I'm on a Debian/Ubuntu based system. I hop around DEs whenever I get bored with my current setup, but I'm comfortable with that foundation.

If I was younger and started using Linux at a time when Arch actually existed, maybe thing would be different.

"Linux Mint 19.1 Will Feature a 'Modern' Desktop Layout - OMG! Ubuntu!"

https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/10/linux-mint-19-1-new-panel-layout

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-31 14:37

@daeh On of the first things I've noticed (and I've only been a user on the system for a day) is the almost radical transparency present in the system. There's a moderation log available for everyone to see where system actions are made public. Everything from username changes to comment deletions. Reasons have to be given for all of it, and those reasons are public. You can even find the invite chain to see how a particular user got on the system. That alone is pretty impressive.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-30 01:35

@kurtm I didn't know that, but I have a mental block against exiting with :x. I always exit one of two ways. It's either :wq, or q!. If I don't know if something was changed, I don't want to save it. Too easy to get changes you didn't want with a :x.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-30 01:32

@SuperFloppies@mastodon.technology In C? Yea, it's a confusing bit. I studied it 20 years ago or so, but haven't used it much since then. Lots of depth.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-30 01:29

@kelbot It's pretty straight forward. Reports come in occasionally, and we handle those reports. Sometimes they're nothing and we close them without doing anything. Sometimes they result in a warning for the individual in question (like cases of naked links or toots in non-English languages), and extreme cases result in accounts being silenced. There are even more extreme cases where accounts get suspended, but those will almost always be discussed in our Keybase chat prior to action.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-29 20:41

@bamfic I think that's the way that it was intended to be used (which is why I think I use it wrong), but it feels weird to me to use it that way because the person who posted is notified. If they weren't notified when you favorited a status, I'd use it more in that fashion.

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-29 20:21

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe They could, but I also know that the way the federation works they could quickly find themselves isolated from the rest of the fed. I know constant and unwelcome attacks against my community would earn an instance that wasn't responsive to those attacks a global silence, and I think many other instances would react the same way. That would result in any radical instances quickly finding themselves screaming into the void.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-29 20:12

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe I'm not certain about that to be honest. I think if they all dumped into a single central instance, yes, they'd bring all those problems with them. If they spread out over the fed and joined smaller instances where the communities they were involved in were more personal, I don't know if they would continue to behave the way they do.I'd like to think they wouldn't, but I have to recognize that they could.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-26 22:33

@tatra Hey, welcome to Fosstodon! If you could do me a favor I'd appreciate it. Fosstodon is an English only instance, so if you're posting to the public timeline, we'd appreciate it if you'd stick to the same language as everybody else. If you're replying to another post or making posts that are unlisted, no worries. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns. Thanks.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-26 19:44

@gairsty Possible. I don't use that particular plugin. Most of what I have is stuff like uBlock, DuckDuckGo Privacy Essentials, and ABP.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-26 19:41

@Wingy From a purely pedantic point, no. There's always going to be a character limit. It may be obscenely high, but every system has an upper limit.

Can you create an instance with an obscenely high limit? Yes. In fact, many Pleroma instances will go to to 5000 characters. Since all of this is open source, I don't see where it would be any problem to go to 50000, or even 500000. Other instances would probably block you pretty fast for being obnoxious though.

@retrohacker

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-24 12:03

@AndrzejL Heh, yep. At this point it looks like someone made a change to one of our firewalls because all of this worked until some time last night, and then it stopped. Both end points have been static in their configuration. Now we're just trying to trace back who changed what and why.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-24 12:00

@jwildeboer I take Cook and Apple with a grain of salt in this particular arena. As much as Apple brags about taking privacy seriously, it's not lost on many that their biggest competition is an advertising company. It's in Apple's best interest if something "bad" happens to Google. This is, of course, after Apple attempted their own social network and their own ad service and they weren't able to compete with the services they're now railing against.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 23:50

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 23:45

@amolith Oh interesting! It's like OneTab but doesn't suck as much!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 23:44

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 23:41

@amolith I also do the same thing with screen sessions, so it's not just tabs. I open a screen, start working on something, and then get distracted and switch to a new session, and open something else. I'll have 5 or 6 sessions all pointing to the same server all in various stages of doing something or another. I do close those more often, and I don't leave them as long, but the same process is at play.

@angelo

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 23:38

@amolith Yea, I don't tend to use bookmarks much, so I open a tab and I leave it open until I'm done with it. I also procrastinate projects, so something I'm researching in December might not be completed until June or later. All the tabs for that project stay open that entire time. I'm not terribly organized either, so sometimes I'll have tabs open on multiple systems for the same projects. Some on my home system, some on my work, some on my phone. Tabs scattered everywhere.

@angelo

4. Article I'm reading in progress.
5. Item I'm considering purchasing.

I rarely deal with bookmarks, so my personal "bookmarking" style is just keep the tab open until I no longer need it. I'm trying to revise this method because it's not very efficient (or remotely efficient).

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 22:56

@angelo I almost always have a ton of tabs. I cleaned out a bunch on my phone today too, and now I'm DOWN to 40. I was in the mid 60s on my phone.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 22:55

@letthewatersroar@toot.cafe I'm not sure how many I had (just cleaned house), but I couldn't read the titles, just see part of the icon. It wasn't quite scrolling at full screen. Easily 25-30?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 22:54

@Indie@x0r.be They're really handy devices to be sure. I'm just not a fan of all the information they collect on us. I'd much rather control my own information and still have the same capabilities.

Imagine a Mycroft system with an in house server, where all of your smart home and applicant functionality was covered, and all external requests were funneled through a VPN and TOR. You'd be able to have all the same functionality and still stay private. Have your cake and eat it too.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 22:50

I only have 5 tabs open in my browser right now. Feels weird.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-22 22:10

I love the IDEA of these devices, but I'm not in love with the fact that these companies are using them as a means to mine data. That's why I'm a supporter of Mycroft. They're working on a personal server you place inside of your home (or business) so that all of your data is kept on prem so you don't need to worry about a company farming your every word. Open source can make these kinds of devices truly useful without sacrificing the privacy of everyone who owns one.

https://www.droid-life.com/2018/10/22/monday-poll-are-you-interested-in-a-smart-display/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-21 05:25

It's been said that procrastination is almost always based on some kind of fear. I'm not opposed to that kind of interpretation, but when I try to analyze my own procrastination, I can't pinpoint anything that really causes fear in the scenario. All I come up with is that things that used to be fun for me are now boring. Crushingly boring. I don't know how to get around that. Even things that feel like they're fun I just can't get started on.

https://zenhabits.net/procrastination-fears/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-18 17:40

@colomar Trollers gunna troll. That's how the Digital Unix server at my university got named "Fubar". The department asked the students, the students submitted ideas, and the muckity mucks talked about the submissions (note: Talked. Almost no one actually READ the list) in a board meeting, and approved "Foobar" without actually checking to see if it was "Foobar" or "Fubar". That server was there for YEARS as a testament to proof reading.

@jwildeboer

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-18 17:34

@kelbot You don't need it, but the OS being aware for alerting purposes would be good. Also, emergency shutdown if your charge drops below a usable threshold wouldn't suck.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-16 23:23

@chadmccullough it's an interesting perspective. I'm not sure how I feel about it. Yes, these genetics companies can use DNA to find people who have similar DNA to the sample, but the same can be said for facial recognition. If you post a selfie, Google or Microsoft or any number of other companies can use that selfie to locate individuals that physically resemble you. Does that make you posting selfies a violation of the privacy of others? Seems weird.

When interacting with bots, please mark your posts as Unlisted or Direct. That way it will not appear in the public timeline, and the bot will still hear you just fine.

There's no way big ad-based companies aren't helping themselves to data from your mic. Your phone and laptop are listening devices. For most of us, this will never have serious ramifications, but still, act accordingly.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-16 15:50

@kelbot I've been using Trello to track notes and progress. It was @Indie@x0r.be that let me in on it. I create an item for a project, and that item stores my notes and links I need for the project. I keep them in swim lanes for "Not Started", "Started", and "Completed". Prioritization is really just which one I'm interested in looking at when I do have a second or two to do it. I don't have a formal method. I do assign due dates on projects when there's something that NEEDS to be done for some reason.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-14 17:07

@aleksandar There's no guarantee Fuchsia will replace anything. At this point it's only experimental and may be nothing at all. ChromeOS? Look at Google's product line:

Phone: Android -> ?
Tablet: Android -> ChromeOS
Laptops: ChromeOS
ChromeCast: ChromeOS
Home Hub: Android Things -> ChromeOS

It's hard not to see a pattern emerging here. Whether we'll see it continue into the phone market is unsure, but I wouldn't be super surprised. A little surprised, but not super.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-14 07:24

@sbani It does, but I've never used it. I like the autofill that I get from the browser plugin, and that doesn't work with the native app. I suppose if I were to switch browsers that could be a sufficient middle ground, but it does complicate my workflow in a way that I'm not a fan of.

@Dobbie03

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-14 07:21

@aleksandar I'd be surprised if it was anything other than Android, but I'm starting to see where it could be ChromeOS. Fuschia is on everybody's mind, but it's years away from being production ready. ChromeOS is here and already has several things in it's favor. Google owns it, it runs Android apps, and Google already has it working in a touch environment on shipping products.

None of this is to say I expect ChromeOS to replace Android next year, but it's closer than before.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-14 06:19

@aleksandar Oh heck no. Google at least tries to be secretive about that sort of thing, even though sometimes they leak like a sieve. The Pixel 3 hasn't even shipped yet, so they haven't even mentioned the Pixel 4, let alone let us in on details about it. It just seems like a direction they may be interested in. I wouldn't be totally shocked if it turned out that way. Not totally.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-14 01:52

@pezzoDiPeco We don't expressly forbid it at this time. If you're posting FROM Fosstodon to Twitter, we don't care. If you're posting from Twitter to Fosstodon, we're not fans. We're trying to build a community here, and dumping posts from a distance without any interaction doesn't do that. Your account might as well be a bot account at that point, and we're not especially fans of that either. Like I said, not forbidden yet, but we ARE keeping an eye on it.

@rotatingskull@sunbeam.city @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 20:41

@aleksandar It's confirmed that the Slate does NOT use Fuchsia. It's a ChromeOS device with a new version of the OS that is optimized for touch interface.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 20:40

@Phaserune Now that would be interesting.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 08:00

@acasajus Possible, but Google was already a billion dollar company in 2008. It paid $50 million for the company and the product, but you can build a heck of an OS for $50 million dollars.

@ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 07:58

@acasajus Fuchsia is an experimental OS that Google has said little to nothing about. The idea that it's designed to replace Android is hypothetical at best. It might be. It might not be. It may never see the light of day on a single product ever.

@ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 07:25

@acasajus I would agree. Linux people can't use it, and normal people just don't care about the underpinnings of their device as long as it works for them. I haven't seen anything that would suggest that it's a liability though. Being open source and modular allows for quite a lot of adaptability, which is why Google runs Linux on their phones (Android), tablets (Android/ChromeOS), laptops (ChromeOS), and servers (Google Linux). They're not acting like it's a liability.

@ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 07:15

@acasajus Well, the problems they've run into haven't really been inherent to Linux, but to Java. Case in point, ChromeOS is also based on Linux.

@ericbuijs

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 07:14

@ericbuijs Fuchsia is an interesting conundrum, but most estimates put it at a couple years away from anything production ready. If they're wanting to replace Android sooner rather than later, they may need an option sooner than Fuchsia will be available.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 07:13

@aleksandar True, but it wouldn't be completely untested because they'd be running it for a full year in a touch capable system with the Slate.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-10-13 04:01

After seeing the way Google has presented ChromeOS on the new Google Slate, I can almost see a Pixel 4 that doesn't use Android. What do you think?

https://www.famousinventors.org/dennis-ritchie

#Introduction

With all the introductions going on I realised I forgot to do one myself so here it is.

I’m an #privacy, #opensource, #opendata and #openstandards advocate. I’m holding a grudge against Big Tech, big IP holders and authoritharian governments. Furthermore I’m a #3Ddesigner, #3Dprinter, #webdesigner and overall #DIY guy.

#introduction

GNU+Linux sysadmin of many years. Dedicated Gentoo user. Ask me about my USE flags!

Daily IRC user for ~15 years.

Amateur keto chef.

Born and raised in the city, but a country boy at heart.

Dog-dad to two rescued mutts who changed my life.

Technological redneck, in the sense of "why yes I rewrote that in bash, why?"

I never did very well with rules.

Live free (as in software) or die.

Person1: Hey Mike, thanks for joining. We were wondering if you can do thing #1.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 21:30

@whiteflag Yea, that's the catch with any new social media network. People don't want to join because there aren't a lot of people there. There aren't a lot of people there because no one wants to join.

The really interesting thing I've found with Mastodon that I haven't found with other social networks is a built in community. Federation means instances exist for all sorts of different interests, each with premade communities to engage with. Even if your wife's cousin's roommate isn't around.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 14:59

@Indie@x0r.be I'm sure it's easier for you with women for two significant reasons. One, personal experience gives you ideas on what works and what doesn't. You have an inside track. Second, the standard for success which I mentioned earlier. I'd be interested to see how your experience would play out if your goal was to actually establish a relationship. It's my guess that flirting for non-heteronormative individuals may be more difficult just due to representation within the general population.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 14:50

@Indie@x0r.be That's what I do! I take something that should be fun for everybody and analyse it down to the minutiae until no one is having fun and everybody is begging me to stop being such a nerd.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 14:46

@Indie@x0r.be I'd actually like to elaborate on this based on my own experience. I find flirting to be much easier these days, mostly because I'm old and married and I'm not expecting anything beyond maybe some witty banter (or not so in my case). When I was younger and more single, I had a much more difficult time of it (which is funny considering I had so much more to work with). So, maybe flirting isn't "easy", its difficulty is directly tied with your investment and your standard for success.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 14:43

@Indie@x0r.be I think it looks good, but really it's to be what you're happy with. If you don't like it, go with something else. My wife went with purple for a long while, and then switched it up to blue for a couple months (these are very dark tints, not bright and super obvious). Lately she did a hair "undye" which was supposed to bring her back to her natural color, but there's still some bleached out color there. She likes it that way though, so she's keeping it for the time being.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-20 14:35

@Indie@x0r.be Doing the math here, there's two attempts at flirting here in this single toot. Rando guy with you and you with the bartender. I'm going to assume definitions of "success" differ in those two cases, so there's a 50/50 success rate for flirting based on that description. I'd argue that most instances of flirting do not end successfully due to instigator's definitions of success. So, yes, you're correct. Flirting is easy (with anybody). Successfully flirting is significantly harder.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 15:23

@lawremipsum@mspsocial.net @emsenn @poetgrant @codesections @kev

I've obviously missed something along the way. What the heck is "bofa" in this context?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 15:05

@emsenn @codesections Neither @kev nor I want the #BDFL kind of setup for Fosstodon. Quite the opposite. @kev was very struck with the debacle around what happened with Void Linux, and so we've intentionally made this a partnership between he and I. We don't run EVERY decision past the community, mostly because we don't think they want to be involved in the minutia. We do want the community to be involved in major decisions that get made, and we feel that's their right.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 14:52

@brandon @anathem @sproid@mastodon.technology I think this is an interesting discussion. Even when you look at Windows, there is a lot of resistance to these new versions. Windows 7 still has the largest piece of the Windows pie with over 42% of Windows users still using a version from almost 10 years ago. It will be interesting to see how much of that is corporate vs. home user, but I think the point stands. macOS's last MAJOR UI revision was the move to OSX back in 2001. They're not making bold moves either.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 14:43

@DistroJunkie Yea, I'm a bit of a pack rat for those kinds of things.

@brandon

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 14:42

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-17 14:35

@poetgrant @codesections @lawremipsum@mspsocial.net I can see this is something @kev and I probably haven't given enough thought. We haven't formalized how the voting process is going to work, and I can see merits in both the 1 person 1 vote approach and giving people who are actually putting funding into the project a little bit more say on where that funding goes.

codesections @codesections 2018-09-16 20:57

I've just released Mastodon De-Mob, an anti-harassment tool that lets users to block everyone who favorited or boosted a toot calling for harassment. https://mastodon-de-mob.codesections.com/

Please feel free to test it out with the example URL I provided; that will only block a test account I set up for this purpose. Hopefully, you won't ever need it for real.

It also reports the harassing toot, which I hope will prevent the tool's abuse for non-harassing toots.

source: https://github.com/codesections/mastodon-de-mob

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-16 17:30

@fatboy No, it's its own thing. A Federated network of sites like Mastodon that also uses the ActivityPub protocol, so it's compatible with Mastodon but not the same. Where Mastodon is "Twitterish", Pixelfed is "Instagramish".

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-16 00:22

@geekygent@mastodon.technology @codesections @Qwxlea

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 21:08

@kelbot Yea, I know the feeling.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:59

@geekygent@mastodon.technology Naw, as long as you're calling the right interpreter in your scripts, it wouldn't impact pre-existing scripts. I'll definitely let everybody know how things go!

@Qwxlea @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:54

@geekygent@mastodon.technology Yea, probably. And that's exactly why I'm wanting to learn this particular shell. If I've been inlining code for a year, it feels stupid to have to figure out how to do that in a different language. I find that bash is fine for most inline tasks, but when I want to convert inline tasks to a script, bash can be limiting. If I was doing inline in python, and then converted to python scripts, that wouldn't be a concern.

@Qwxlea @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:51

@geekygent@mastodon.technology It's not really the number of computers that makes things so variable, but the variability between customers. How they want files packaged, naming conventions, encryption keys, remote file paths, etc. If you were going to try to code that into a static script, it's pretty nasty. A one time inline script for a particular customer doesn't have to deal with all of those variables, but it's probably going to be next to useless the next time around.

@codesections @Qwxlea

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:47

@Qwxlea I've found myself wishing for 2D arrays before, but admittedly not in an inline script. The problem I've run into in the past is when something I've been doing inline forever suddenly needs a more permanent solution. More things have to be compensated for, and things just get more complex. Then I want to take what I've been using inline and expand that into an actual script. Sometimes the limited capabilities of standard shells makes that more difficult.

@geekygent@mastodon.technology @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:44

@joseph Glad to hear it. I was watching the news showing what was going on over there and was concerned. I knew you were getting evacuated, but was still worried. Hopefully things are good when you get back to your house Monday. Please keep us in the loop so we know what's going on.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:34

@joseph Hey, how's things going over there? Haven't heard from you for a while.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:29

@geekygent@mastodon.technology That's definitely a concern. A good part of my job is encrypted data transfer. Usually this stuff all happens though our automation, but I come in when things don't work. In those cases, I'm pulling large numbers of files (sometimes thousands) and having to encrypt/decrypt and/or load data to databases or send that data to remote services. I've just gotten lazy in my old age, and I prefer to type in a couple lines of code and go get coffee.

@codesections @Qwxlea

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:14

@vosaxalo Agreed. I'm not sure what the author was getting at with that comparison. Maybe they just stopped using forums and they thought everybody else did as well?

@codesections @danyspin97

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-15 19:12

@codesections @Qwxlea For me, I live in the shell. It's not a place I drop into for a quick command or two and I'm done. I spend the larger portion of my work day in a shell. I constantly write inline shell scripts for one time use throughout the day, so I can deal with multiple things programmatically rather than manually. There has been more than one occasion where I've wished I had access to 2D arrays in bash. I can see your points, but for me this may be a real benefit.

@skiryazov It doesn't. The browser compensates for what it considers "bad code" or possible corruption in a file automatically. Because of that, the browser interprets this file differently depending on how it's referenced. Crazy right?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-09 20:24

@lukewrites Following other instances is pretty easy. Use the Search and there's an option to search for instances. Find the instance you're interested in, and tap the View Instance button. Once you can see their timeline, there's an Add to Home button, that will add that timeline right to your home screen. Pretty cool feature. I don't know that any other client does that.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:32

@Indie@x0r.be And how did it go?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:23

@jaycee Good night!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:19

@jaycee A federation bot is just a bot account. Because of how the federation works, your federated timeline is filled with posts from instances your instance is aware of, so people have written bots to auto follow other people so it can see who they're following so it can follow them. By doing this, it discovers other instances which populate it's federated timeline. You can block or ignore, but there's no real point in following back.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:15

@jaycee You're very welcome! Welcome to Mastodon!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:11

@jaycee Also, if you click the gear icon above your post, and go to your preferences, you can see how your Toots will automatically show up right below the languages. If you'd prefer Public instead of Unlisted (or vise versa), you can change it there.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 23:08

@jaycee I see a post from you starting "Well, as I'm new... ". When you're posting (and I can't see if you did this or not, so sorry if I'm repeating myself), make sure the icons below the text box, the second one should be a globe. If it's not, click on it and change it. I noticed that these are coming in as "Unlisted". That might be the problem.

Ellie @noelle 2018-09-08 01:59

Okay. #mastoadmin commentary time.

I've written a quick guide, So You're A Mastodon Moderator: https://noelle.codes/so_youre_a_mastodon_moderator.pdf

My goal for this is threefold:

* I want to create a useful reference for moderators, so they know what options are available.
* I want to create a useful reference for /users/, so they know what the powers and limitations of being a moderator are.
* I want to help establish a /standard of moderation/, so we're all on a level playing field.

@poetgrant @puffinux @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 00:59

@brandon Sure, but the code we were working on was fairly in depth. One of them was 120 pages printed. I was looking for a better way.

@poetgrant @puffinux @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 00:30

@brandon Yea, I'm pretty sure he didn't work with it that way. He just ran a search and replace on all his variables before he handed the code off to me I think. I wasn't a fan. I had to write my own program to read his code and replace all the variables with readable names. It didn't work that well because it was parsing code, and that can be a complex thing. Things ended up broken a lot, which made more work for me.

@poetgrant @puffinux @codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-08 00:24

aAAAAA
AaAAAA
AAaAAA
AAAaAA
AAAAaA
AAAAAa
aaAAAA
etc.

@joseph @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-07 16:22

@codesections The whole "why should we care?" bit was a hyperbolic paraphrase by the author, and when the facts are looked at, I think their response is reasonable. It's also possible to "subvert" their encryption if there's a keylogger installed on the computer. This makes sense based on attack vector. If the browser is compromised in some way, things typed into the browser are not secure. On a whole, this issue doesn't concern me.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-05 14:21

@davidws Any time.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-09-05 14:20

@davidws Well, stopping someone from joining is pretty straight forward. In Administration/Site Settings section of your preferences, just uncheck the "Open Registration". After that, make sure to adjust the "Allow invitations by" section to reflect what permissions level you want to be able to issue Invitations. As far as moderation rules, you can borrow a Code of Conduct from us or another site, but you'll need to enforce that code manually from the Moderation section of your settings.

Mike Stone boosted
codesections @codesections 2018-09-04 22:12

The Mastodon GitHub repo currently has 3 open issues that could help moderators moderate better:

- Add a moderation API: let third-party devs build better tools for moderation, much like the various mobile clients. https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/issues/8580
- Add Locked account state: let mods to temporarily lock accounts (like a forum ban) without kicking the user out. https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/issues/7273
- Add public info about number of mods/instance: let people find instances with more mods/user. https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/issues/8557

Eugen Rochko @Gargron 2018-09-04 21:05

Mastodon is written in Ruby. The creator of Ruby, @matz is on Mastodon (albeit inactive). Mastodon uses Sidekiq for background processing. The creator of Sidekiq, @mperham is on Mastodon. It's kind of a bizarre feeling.

Fosstodon @fosstodon 2018-09-01 07:48

Our admin, @mike had a great idea - to open up the Fosstodon Hub to our users, so they can contribute blog posts.

Maybe you want to talk about a project you're interested in, or something you're working on, or maybe just tell people why you use FOSS in a more long-form fashion.

Think of it kinda like a mini-medium for Fosstodon users.

This post is to gauge interest before we start developing something. Would anyone be interested in contributing to, or consuming, such content?

@sproid@mastodon.technology I do listen to music or podcasts, but it still feels like I'm trying to FIND something to put into that time rather than be doing something I need or want to do.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-30 20:01

@kelbot I'd love to be able to do it. Unfortunately distance, temperature, and a frankly bicycle hostile environment make that impossible for the time being.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-30 18:12

@kelbot Agreed. Even if you're in one of the biggest cities, it can be ridiculous. My drive in to my office (non rush hour) is about 25 minutes, but trying to take public transit would take more than 2 hours longer (each way!). It's over 20 miles from my home, and it would still be faster to ride a bike.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-30 18:02

@kelbot I'm fortunate in that I only really have to go into my office once a week. It's nice to be able to stay home and not worry about traffic and dress codes and security badges and blah blah blah. It saves me on child care and fast food lunches. Even when I do have to go in, my schedule is flexible enough that I avoid most traffic by coming in later. Still, I'd rather be spending the time I AM driving doing something else more productive than turning a wheel and pushing with my foot.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-30 17:54

@codemonkey I used to be an adventurer like you.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-30 17:51

For the Americans out there, how much of your life you're going to spend commuting (assuming you do that). From the looks of things, I could be spending over a year of my life staring at tail lights. This is where working at home is really beneficial. I can better make use of that time. Hopefully self-driving cars are right around the corner, where everybody in the car can engage in something else other than driving.

https://www.educateddriver.org/heres-how-much-time-youll-waste-commuting-in-your-lifetime-by-city/

codesections @codesections 2018-08-29 20:10

My experience when writing HTML just got a lot more pleasant (and colorful) thanks to a #vim plugin: https://github.com/luochen1990/rainbow. It color-codes matching opening and closing HTML tags (and matching parentheses/brackets)in code. This makes it *much* easier to avoid miss-indenting code—one of those errors that can really drive you crazy.

H/T @sjl whose classic post, Coming Home To Vim, http://stevelosh.com/blog/2010/09/coming-home-to-vim/ mentions a similar plugin (I'd forgotten until I re-read the post, which I recommend)

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-29 20:17

@Jamest Sounds nice actually.

Mike Stone boosted
Tusky @Tusky 2018-08-26 12:38

One of the most frequent questions we get is: Why doesn't Tusky support push notifications?

Because pushing to devices would require us to use proprietary Google libraries and to run a relay server. But we want Tusky to be pure FOSS (free and open-source software) and don't want to send any data to Google so we decided not to implement push notifications at this time. We are researching other possibilities to make notifications faster though.
https://github.com/tuskyapp/Tusky/issues/793

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-26 16:17

@unicornfarts That's weird. I've run a couple things with Proton, and my NVideo X Server Settings say my current driver version is 390.48.

I don't know how they would classify our home if it was for Net Neutrality issues.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-24 22:51

Wow! I can't believe I almost let this slide by without mentioning it!

Happy 23rd Birthday Windows 95!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-24 22:30

@mooshoe Hm, put me on the spot. The Welcome Screen is great, the Software Manager has built in flatpak integration. Easy control panels that put Windows to shame. Timeshift for backup works really well (I haven't had to restore yet). Mostly it's a cohesiveness to the UI that makes the experience more uniform. It's hard to describe. It runs well even in a VM if you want to give it a shot. I'd recommend it.

codesections @codesections 2018-08-24 20:14

@Luca's data visualizations of the Fediverse are **fascinating** (links below)

A couple of #fosstodon points jump out at me.

First: we're not as tiny as I thought! It's hard to tell in detail from the graph, but we look to be firmly mid-sized as far as instances go.

Second, we're right on the edge between two clusters: "English" and "Non-Tech-Niche"—odd given the *extreme* tech focus we've got.

Very interesting.

Thread: https://vis.social/@Luca/100605368604172253

SVG: https://lucahammer.at/vis/fediverse/2018-08-24-fediverse-min.svg

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-24 21:02

@codesections @mooshoe I've been trying it out after years. It's not doing anything that most other DEs don't do, but it has got a very polished feel, and it's tools and setup is very elegant (for lack of a better word). It's not that what it's doing is unique, it's just done very well. Did that mean anything to anybody?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-23 23:10

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-23 23:09

@wakest @simon_brooke @lukeoneil47 There's also the Local feed that isn't being taken into consideration here. Some instances, like mastodon.social, are general instances. They don't have a "theme" for lack of a better word. Other instances, like my own, are for people to congregate and discuss something they're all fans of. By joining an instance you can get a built in community who all have similar interests as yours. You don't need to search all over the Fed, they're already there.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-23 23:04

@pezzoDiPeco I don't know, but that could be pretty funny. Given enough time, there could be a Mastodon instance for just about anything!

Fosstodon @fosstodon 2018-08-23 20:24

We wrote a post about why we decided to go English only on Fosstodon. If you're interested in a long-form explaination as to why we did it, check out this post:

https://hub.fosstodon.org/why-fosstodon-is-an-english-only-instance/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-23 22:14

@nerdhochburg @fosstodon Boosting is fine because, like replies, they don't show up in the local feed. Further, it's really just a link to another persons post, and their posts follow different rules than ours.

Mike Stone boosted
Gwmngilfen @gwmngilfen 2018-08-23 19:18

Day 1 of playing with Valve's new Proton software.

It's awesome. Seriously, this is a game changer. The ability to play a game with no Linux version *and have it show as a Linux sale* to the developer, is great. This is what we needed, as it allows us to use Wine without the nagging feeling that we're undermining ourselves by reducing the apparent market share.

Now I need to learn how to rebuild Proton so I can include a 2line patch for Path of Exile.

#gameing #steam #valve #proton

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-22 23:03

@lukeoneil47 @wakest It comes across as Mastodon is a collection of isolated islands, it's the opposite. Joining an instance gives you instant access to a Local feed of individuals who may share your specific interests. There is no analog on Twitter. Once you're on the instance though, you can still follow individuals and interact with anybody on any other instance of Mastodon. This works EXACTLY like Twitter does. By default, Mastodon is LESS isolated than Twitter, and finding people is easier.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-22 23:00

@wilw I might have my next project. If it works, it could pay for itself!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-22 22:53

@DistroJunkie Really, anybody of any import, be they a CEO of a company or a politician, should not be relying on password only security. Unfortunately there's not enough technological understanding in the average person and security is often an overlooked issue. You know, until someone else gets elected.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-22 22:33

@Jamest Wow, the 4 can support up to 32, but that still seems like a really low number. Maybe they're assuming you're going to secure things like your computer and your phone, and you'll use another service with those devices and 2FA instead of using the key for all the sites you visit.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-21 14:32

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-21 14:32

@crodges It's an interesting conundrum. I don't want AI under the control of a few powerful corporations, but there are a lot of things that AI can be used for that that range from "bad" to flat out "evil" we would have no chance of containing with AI given to the public as FLOSS. It's worth considering that a non-FLOSS AI company is just as capable of doing "evil" things with AI. We just probably wouldn't know about it until it was too late.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-20 23:28

https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/what-does-ethical-ai-mean-open-source

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-20 17:45

@deadsuperhero @0x1C3B00DA

#BLOCKCHAIN!!! Do it! Do it!!

I'm kidding. I am glad that it's being worked on because I do feel that this is a one of the more frustrating things about #ActivityPub integration. It's like having multiple accounts that SHOULD work together, and kind of do, but kind of don't. Even tying accounts together in some way would be preferable. If I post on my #PixelFed account, it automatically posts that content to my Mastodon account? That would work, but the inverse?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-20 17:20

@idiom Glad to hear it! There's a lot of interesting services that are using #ActivityPub right now, and I'm a fan of them. I hope my post doesn't discourage you from trying them out.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-20 17:02

My one frustration with #ActivityPub federated stuff right now is that they integrate, but only partially. I have this account, but I can't use this account to access #PixelFed. I have to create an account on pixelfed.social, and then I can follow myself from my Mastodon account? People who follow me here on Fosstodon don't follow the PixelFed account. I COULD boost my PixelFed account from Mastodon, but things just get awkward. Then we add #PeerTube into the mix, or other federated stuff.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-19 04:46

@brandon Yea. It's 9:45PM right now, and it's currently 38C. It's a dry heat, but people still die in it. ☠️

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-19 03:12

@ktweed I'd agree that it's difficult to get people to use it. I think the main reason for that is that they're trying to sell encryption as the feature, when most people don't care a lot about it. Encryption is a feature that is a "nice to have" in the minds of most people on the Internet. To get people to use it, you've got to have something else as a "killer feature" and have the encryption be something that's there too.

@aadilayub @kev @joseph

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-19 03:00

@brandon

I use it for lots of things. I use the encrypted git for a personal backup. All the communication between myself, @kev, and @joseph that isn't done directly on Fosstodon is done on Keybase. I use it for secure file transfer, and even an open source replacement for Dropbox.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-17 22:54

@Megaf I'm on Bob Seger right now, but my music is on random, so you never know what's coming next!

Yep, unlike Twitter when you post on Mastodon everybody on your local instance automatically sees your posts. The Fed too, but that's really hard to pick out because of the massive flow of posts that goes through there. They don't just fly out into space. Add to that by posting your interests with hash tags, you've made it easy for people with similar interests to find you.

Michael Hall @mhall119 2018-08-17 15:35

I just became a monthly patron of @fosstodon

https://www.patreon.com/fosstodon/

If you like Mastodon and want to see it succeed and replace Twitter, you need to support your instance too.

By helping pay for the hosting and maintenance of your instance you will not only make sure it can keep running, but you also give the admins a reason to ensure that it's run and moderated to your liking.

If you're an instance admin, let people know how to support you.

#SupportFederation
@kev @switchingsocial@mastodon.at

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-17 14:55

@Indie@x0r.be @kev Though the caveat to that is replies don't show up in the local feed or the fed. Only for people following you. You have to put out your own posts.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-17 14:54

@Indie@x0r.be @kev It's not as hard as Twitter for example. On birdsite, when you post it's basically going out into the ether and unless someone is following you, no one sees it. On Mastodon, everything you post (that you don't mark as private) is visible to others on your instance through the local feed, and basically everybody on the Fed. When you say something people like, they're going to follow. Discoverability is a lot better on Mastodon than Twitter in my opinion.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-17 14:51

@Indie@x0r.be @kev Good deal! So, now you're getting content from your local users. Time to make some new friends!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-13 17:29

@mooshoe @kev @Modern_Industrial I think Mastodon's decentralized nature plays into the focus on interests and less on "Friends". You join an instance that's topically interesting for you, and it immediately gives you a local feed of people who have similar interests. Your friends and family probably aren't there, but it's provided a mechanism for us to meet new people.
